United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Proceedings of the conference, pp. 295-384
			
 PDF (32.5 MB) 



Page 327


PROCEEDINGS OF THE CONFERENCE
gold and do business largely within the Empire.' Lord Cherwell pooh
poohed this idea of the Prime Minister's.
 "Admiral Leahy seemed on the whole to b:>e unsympathetic to the
Treasury's program and to side with Churchill. Admiral Leahy
thought the only way to assure peace in the future was for the United
States, the United Kingdom and possibly Russia 'if she behaves her-
self' to 'crack down' on any country which stepped over the boundary
line of any other country.
 "The President said very little in reply to Churchill's views. Secre-
tary Morgenthau several times interjected into Churchill's commentis
that his program did not recommend that Germany be permitted to
starve as seemed to be the implication in Churchill's remark.
 "At another point when discussing the need for an international
police air force Churchill said that the United States, United Kin gdom
and Russia would have to rotate the job 'as our air people get dirty
wlhen they associate with the Russi ans.'
 "At one point in the discussion Churchill said to the President: 'Is
this what y ou asked me to come all the way over here to discuss?'
 "The conversation then got on to India arid staved on liIdia for
about an hour. Churchill talked rather angrily at length about the
difficulties the British were confronted with in- administering India
and on the lack of understanding in the United States about the Indian
problem. He spoke of the high birth rate, the high death rate, the
ignorance and the carelessness of the Indian people to poverty, disease,
etc. Churchill said, 'I will give the United States half of lndia to
admninister and we will take the other half and we will see who does
better with each other's half.'
 "However, the President caine back to the German problem several
times very nicely and did not recede from his position. He reminded
Churchill that Stalin at Teheran had said: 'Are you g oi-ng to let Ger-
many produce, modern metal furniture? The manlluacture of metal
furniture can be quickly turned into the manufacture off ar )nanonh' 6
 "Lord Cherwell seemed to be in sympathy with the Secretari es
point of view. Later when talking it over with him hee said that "he
didn't think that Churchill at all got the major point the Secretary
was trying to make. The Secretary asked him if he didncli think the
real difficulty with Churchill was that he wanted a strong G-erlmany
to stand between 'the white, cliffs of Dover' and Coinmmunisis Russia.
Cherwell agreed that that was it. Lord Leathers of the Shippilln 13Boatrd
apparently disagreed with the Secretary's point of view.
 "On leaving, Lord Cherwell said that he expected to talk fwith the
Secretary about lend-lease assistance for the period bet-ween the defeat
of Germany and the defeat of Japan. The Secre'Clary told himt thlat he
had been asked by the President to come to tIalk about Germany but
after [that2] he would be glad to discuss lend-lease ai(i the followilng
morning after they had had their convevPst)voa abouut Gerniamt-v.
 "The Secretary had an opportunity to tell the President; that he
believed the Russians were holding back on their cooperavtion with tile
United States because they were suspicious of the American and
British attitude toward Germany. Russia feared we and tile British
were going to try to make a soft peace with Germany and build her
' See Foreign Relations, The Conferences at Cairo and Tehran, 1943, pp. 511,
880.
